citations.narrative:
The facility is not keeping copies of health certificates for dogs they transport. Appropriate record keeping is important for
a facility to ensure that the standards of the Animal Welfare Act regulations are being met. Intermediate transporters and
carriers shall keep and maintain a copy of the health certificate completed for any live dog transported. These records
should then be kept for 1 year. Correct by: March 14, 2024.

The facility is receiving live dogs for transport without a health certificate. Health certificates are important when
transporting dogs in order to ensure the animal is free of communicable or contagious diseases and is in good health for
the rigors of transportation. An intermediate handler or carrier may not receive a dog for transportation unless it is
accompanied by a health certificate issued within 10 days by a licensed veterinarian. Correct by: March 14, 2024.

citations.desc: Primary enclosures used to transport live dogs and cats.
citations.narrative:
The transport enclosures used by the facility do not have "Live Animal" and arrow labeling. Proper labeling of an
enclosure is important for the safety of the animals during transportation, and especially should an emergency arise.
Since the enclosures are not permanently affixed to the transport conveyance (truck/van, etc), the words “Live Animal”
need to be clearly marked in letters at least 1 inch in height on the top and on at least one side of the enclosure, and with
arrows indicating the correct upright position of the enclosure. Correct by: March 14, 2024.

citations.desc: Primary enclosures used to transport live dogs and cats.
citations.narrative:
The transport enclosures the facility is using do not have projecting rims. Projecting rims are important as they allow air
flow between adjacent enclosures which improves ventilation and temperature regulation to the animals housed within.
Since the transport enclosures are not permanently affixed to the conveyance (truck/van, etc), a projecting rim of at least
0.75 inches must be added to the exterior of each enclosure wall that has a ventilation opening. Correct by: March 14,
2024
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the registrant.
